meanings.definition: To make feel uncomfortable because of shame or receiving too much attention from others.
examples: I was embarassed when I realized I forgot to do today's homework.

images.description: Drawing of an emoticon with wide open eyes, red cheeks, and a slightly frowning mouth.
images.caption: Blushing, or having your cheeks turn red, can be a sign that you are embarrassed.

meanings.definition: A single event that takes place.
examples: In two separate incidents, two cyclists were hit while biking on city streets.

images.alt: Photo of a crushed car and ambulance.
images.description: The photo shows a car with a crushed front section. Small pieces of plastic and glass are on the road around the car. The airbag in the car can be seen at the driver's seat. An ambulance is parked on the other side of the road near the crushed car.
images.caption: A car accident is an example of an incident that every driver hopes will never happen again.

meanings.definition: To make feel uncomfortable because of shame or receiving too much attention from others.
examples: I was mortified when my personal secret was shared with the class.

meanings.definition: People who watch or are at an event, but are not part of it.
examples: Onlookers watched as the ocean waves caused by a storm destroyed a building on the shore.

meanings.definition: To change something that is happening or might happen.
examples: Seeing the two people argue, another person decided to intercede to prevent a fight.

images.alt: Photo of three people on a stage.
images.description: Two men approaching each other with another man standing between them.
images.caption: The person in the middle intercedes between the others.

source.title: Play-acting to try to train GIs to intervene agaisnt sexual harrassment and sexual assault
source.author: Aleah M. Castrejon

meanings.definition: A single event that takes place.
examples: A solar eclipse is an occurrence that does not happen very often.

images.alt: Photo of a crushed car and ambulance.
images.description: The photo shows a car with a crushed front section. Small pieces of plastic and glass are on the road around the car. The airbag in the car can be seen at the driver's seat. An ambulance is parked on the other side of the road near the crushed car.
images.caption: A car accident is an occurence that everyone hopes will never happen.

meanings.definition: To be responsible for doing something wrong.
examples: Should someone be held culpable if they see a crime happen but do not report it to the police?
We are amending our class rules to add that we should listen to other people's opinions.

images.alt: Photo of printed book and manuscript page.
images.description: This photo shows a page of printed text on the left side, and a handwritten manuscript on the right side. The manuscript on the right side has words written, crossed out, and other words added.
images.caption: Crossed out sections and added words shows the author spent time amending this text.

source.title: Newton's Annotated copy of his Principia Mathematica
source.author: Billthom

examples: Flour, butter, and sugar consitute the main ingredients of cookies.

images.alt: Photo of two different kinds of cookies on a plate
images.description: The photo shows a plate filled with cookies. Some of the cookies are a very light brown with a small dark brown cone chocolate in the center. The other cookies are oval and have a shiny flat orange area in the center.
images.caption: Though some are different from each other, these all consitute types of cookies.

meanings.definition: The quality of being fair and reasonable.
examples: We were guided by our belief in equity when we divided the money equally to all the workers.

images.alt: Photo of swimmers starting a race together.
images.description: Photo shows a row of people as they lean forward to dive into a pool of water. The swimmers are each on platforms that are identical to each other in shape and height. Each platform has a number on its sides.
images.caption: In this race, it is a matter of equity that everyone starts at the same time and the same place.

examples: Should politicians pass legislation to require recycling, or should people decide on their own?

images.description: Exterior photo of a building with a large white dome. The dome is at the center of the building and has a statue of a person at its top. A large columned building section is below the dome, and identical wings or sides of the building extend out to the right and left of the columned section. Two sets of stairs lead up toward the two wings of the building.
images.caption: National laws are created in the U.S. Congress.

source.title: Washington DC - Capitol Hill: United States Capitol
source.author: Wally Gobetz

meanings.definition: To bring to an end; to solve.
examples: We resolved our argument and agreed to be friends again.

meanings.definition: To change something that is happening or might happen.
examples: When Daneesh saw the cat being chased by her dog, she intervened by getting her dog to come over to her, instead.

meanings.definition: People who watch or are at an event, but are not part of it.
examples: Bystanders watched as the firefighters put out the fire.

meanings.definition: Information shared by one person to another without any proof that it is true.
examples: The rumors that some people had cheated on the test were not true.
Is someone guilty of a crime if they see something illegal happen and do not report it to the police?

meanings.definition: Information shared by one person to another without any proof that it is true.
examples: Unless you hear it on the news, don't believe the hearsay that school will be cancelled tomorrow.
